comments.commentBody: Nothing in your post makes sense, with all due respect. Inequality is the severity of the gap between the poor and middle, and the middle and rich. Today, those who work the hardest are often paid the least, while those who work the least are paid the most (even when we exclude those in Congress). We have seen decades of upward wealth redistribution, and the results are seen in the dramatic deterioration of the US in virtually every respect. As much as it offends our egos, the US is no longer a world leader. While corporate profits have soared, the overall quality of life in the US has fallen from #1 when Reagan first took office, down to #11, and it's still falling, making the nations collapse likely. Why do you think that it isn't the poor who lose? It is impossible to address inequality/our overall economic condition while excluding the huge portion of the population in poverty. No, there is no way to discuss inequality without addressing poverty.

Others have brought up many of the flaws, also recognized by the author. But there is an additional large error of interpretation: inequality is not the same thing as poverty.

You can have inequality without the large percentages of people that are poor and conversely you can have poverty without large inequality.

It becomes an interesting question: How much of the large increase in wealth at the top end of the redistribution of income that would otherwise have gone to those with lower incomes (and who loses - my guess is not the poor).

There are many negative outcomes of inequality, not poverty. (like incarceration rates, obesity, and others) We need to talk seriously about inequality and separately about poverty. This might make conversations more possible, since it does not bring into play conservative assumptions about why people are poor.

When the pope says to love and help the poor, suddenly the whole Republican party tries to discredit him.

The liberal/academic mindset loves to criticize the US and its institutions. JesseC is an extreme example, equating Kent State with Tiananmen Square, but less extreme versions are common.

When one views US/Western institutions as morally bankrupt, then it is harder to object to university partnerships with problematic host countries; the expansion appears to be from one bad country (the US) to other bad countries.

Certainly our democracy needs US academics to be willing to criticize US institutions. But a reflexive monotone disgust is not a mark of discernment. Nor is it heroic. Criticizing an authoritarian regime from the inside takes real courage; criticizing a liberal democracy does not.

Chinese University Defends Outspoken Teacher’s Firing
By ANDREW JACOBS
Published: October 25, 2013
http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/26/world/asia/chinese-university-defends-...

I can't pretend to know the internal politics of a Chinese university (perhaps some "outspoken" faculty have managed to keep their jobs? perhaps Xia really isn't an inspiring or gifted lecturer?) but I can speak on what American universities purport to stand for. Your comment misses entirely the thrust of this discussion. Xia is one professor - the question is, should U.S. universities create partnerships in China AT ALL? It clearly represents a compromise of their ideals for a financially beneficial arrangement. As other commenters have pointed out, it is probably naive to think American institutions of higher learning are any different from businesses or corporations at this point. But this is one of the most cynical manifestations of that discomforting reality. If we believe in the model and values of a liberal education, in even the slightest potential that a university can represent an intellectual safe haven from monied interests, we have to be vociferously opposed to what is happening here. It is appalling and wrong. And I don't have to believe you are a Chinese government troll c.pu to know that your reaction is also wrong. Kudos to Yale which seems to be, for the moment, the school closest to a principled,  honest reckoning on this issue.

According to various students from Peking University, Xia isn't such a great teacher as the media tends to depict him. He spends a lot of time discussing the so-called "ideologies", but not substantial academic material. China is no longer the China that the West is used to seeing. Many Chinese college students are not blind to the authoritarian nature of Chinese government, and they normally don't identify themselves as supporters of the communism party. This whole issue about Xia is overly politicized. There are many outspoken liberal professors at Peking University who have been at their job for a long time despite the fact that they have oftentimes spoken against certain government policies.
Why, you may ask? Because they are great teachers, and students love them. However, Xia is simply not at their level.

Just because an apple and an orange are placed next to each other does not make them the same thing. Your basis for the 1st and 2nd Amendments' equivalency is that they were "enshrined" in the same document. This does not make them inherently equal. The 3/5 compromise was so "enshrined" in our nation's Constitution (though not specifically a part of the Bill of Rights), and that does not mean it is an law equal in foresight and justice as the right to freely practice one's religion. (It is of course one of the most racist and degrading laws ever written in this nation's history). Amendments have also been changed in the past, so there is a precedent for updating antiquated laws when needed.

I think professor Gutting has it right that as soon as the discussion is framed as a removal of rights, a tiny, well-organized faction of gun-owners spends a ton of money out of fear that the men in black helicopters are going to come take their guns. As other comments have pointed out, fear is a great motivator here, and when it is the fear that a RIGHT is going to be taken away, people hold onto their guns with white-knuckles wrapped around their nickel-plated grips. But if the reason they need a gun is it is their right, then it is totally circular. Critically examining the need for a gun in the first place is what this article is about.

I would also suggest you re-examine your implicit analogy that Islam is as much to blame for 9/11 as assault rifles are for Sandy Hook and Aurora.

Charitable giving, while often done from the goodness of one's heart (and just as often done for the tax deduction), essentially takes the government off the hook in doing its job of providing for the well-being and security of its people. It's no surprise that the most advanced countries have much lower rates of charity and poor countries have much higher rates. Why? Because rich countries are better able to afford to take care of its people, arts, infrastructure, animals, etc. because they have the means to do so through taxes (the best and most efficient charitable system). Poor countries must rely on family and friends because the government does not have such means.

The US is in an intermediate situation. The government is starved for funds for its people's well-being (although there is plenty of money to bailout the banksters, fund the military-industrial-complex, subsidize the rich in very many ways) because of a host of tax loopholes and deductions geared towards keeping people like myself quite comfortable indeed. Meanwhile, it cannot fund a decent education or health care system and stands helpless (like a third world country) when a disaster like Hurricane Katrina occurs. Many well-meaning people step up to the plate to provide charity for the aforementioned crises. The fact that this occurs is because the government has failed. Charitable giving has its place. I give it myself, but charity should not be making up for a society's failing.
